DataElement.preferredDefinition: Indicator of whether or not a participant has family history of lung cancer.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A person related by descent rather than by marriage or law._Chronological record of health and disease events of family members and ancestors. (WEBS84)._A carcinoma originating in the lung.  Lung carcinomas usually arise from the epithelium that lines the bronchial tree (bronchogenic carcinomas), and are classified as small cell or non-small cell carcinomas.  Non-small cell lung carcinomas are usually adenocarcinomas, squamous cell carcinomas, or large cell carcinomas.  Metastatic carcinomas to the lung are also common, and can be difficult to distinguish from primary tumors. -- 2004_Occurrence; an instance of something happening.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A person related by descent rather than by marriage or law.:Chronological record of health and disease events of family members and ancestors. (WEBS84)

Concepts.definition: A person related by descent rather than by marriage or law.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and disease events of blood relatives. A patient's family medical history may be important in diagnosing existing conditions.

Property.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma originating in the lung.  Lung carcinomas usually arise from the epithelium that lines the bronchial tree (bronchogenic carcinomas), and are classified as small cell or non-small cell carcinomas.  Non-small cell lung carcinomas are usually adenocarcinomas, squamous cell carcinomas, or large cell carcinomas.  Metastatic carcinomas to the lung are also common, and can be difficult to distinguish from primary tumors. -- 2004:Occurrence; an instance of something happening.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma originating in the lung. Lung carcinomas usually arise from the epithelium that lines the bronchial tree (bronchogenic carcinomas), and are classified as small cell or non-small cell carcinomas. Non-small cell lung carcinomas are usually adenocarcinomas, squamous cell carcinomas, or large cell carcinomas. Metastatic carcinomas to the lung are also common, and can be difficult to distinguish from primary tumors.
An instance of something happening, such as an event or incident.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Released per approval by S.Shakour and D.Reeves 12/1/11 mc
